Iltutmish's power was precarious, and several Muslim amirs (nobles) challenged his authority as they had been supporters of Qutb al-Din Aibak.

Imran Ahmed Khan Niazi[a] (born 5 October 1952) is a Pakistani former cricketer, philanthropist, and politician who served as the 19th prime minister of Pakistan from August 2018 until April 2022.
Imran Khan ascended to leadership in 2018 with the backing of the military, but was subsequently removed from power in 2022 after losing that support.
Imran Khan began mobilising workers on 29 October 2016 to lockdown Islamabad, demanding Nawaz's resignation and a corruption inquiry.
Imran Khan in his book, Pakistan: A Personal History, recalled an incident before a 1987 Cricket World Cup warm-up match against the West Indies at Gaddafi Stadium.
Imran Khan was arrested on 9 May 2023 in a controversial move by paramilitary forces, and has remained imprisoned since August 2023, with major protests still ongoing for his release.
Imran Khan was elected Prime Minister with Arif Alvi, Khan's close ally, as president.
Imran, concerned for Sharif's safety against the West Indies' formidable pace attack, asked if an ambulance was ready.
In "Gulshan-e-Raz-e-Jadeed", Iqbal first poses questions, then answers them with the help of ancient and modern insight.
In 1160, Muhammad Ghori conquered Ghazni from the Ghaznavids and became its governor in 1173.
In 1186–87, he conquered Lahore, bringing the last of Ghaznevid territory under his control and ending the Ghaznavid Empire.
In 1335, Jalaluddin Ahsan Khan, a Sayyid native of Kaithal in North India, revolted and founded the Madurai Sultanate in South India.
In 1526, Timurid ruler Babur invaded northern India and conquered the Sultanate, leading to its succession by the Mughal Empire.
In 1551, Hindal Mirza died fighting in a battle against Kamran Mirza's forces.
In 1555, while Akbar was still a child, the Ottoman Admiral Seydi Ali Reis visited the Mughal Emperor Humayun.
In 1558, Akbar took possession of Ajmer, the aperture to Rajputana, after the defeat and flight of its Muslim ruler.
In 1558, while Akbar was consolidating his rule over northern India, Safavid Shah Tahmasp I seized Kandahar and expelled its Mughal governor.
In 1560, Akbar resumed military operations.
In 1562, Akbar married the former wife of Abdul Wasi, the son of Shaikh Bada, lord of Agra.
In 1564, Mughal forces began the conquest of Garha, a thinly populated, hilly area in central India that was of interest to the Mughals because of its herd of wild elephants.
In 1564, he sent presents to the court with a request that his daughter be married to Akbar.
In 1566, Akbar moved to meet the forces of his brother, Muhammad Hakim, who had marched into the Punjab with the intention of seizing the imperial throne.
In 1567, Akbar attacked the Chittor Fort in Mewar.
In 1569, during the early years of Akbar's rule, Ottoman Admiral Kurtoğlu Hızır Reis visited the Empire.
In 1572, Sulaiman Khan's son, Daud Khan, succeeded him.
In 1572, the Mughal Empire annexed Gujarat and acquired its first access to the sea, but local officials informed Akbar that the Portuguese had begun to exert control in the Indian Ocean.
In 1573, Akbar issued a firman directing Mughal administrative officials in Gujarat not to provoke the Portuguese in the territory they held in Daman.
In 1577, Francis Drake set out on an expedition from England to plunder Spanish settlements in South America in search of gold and silver.
In 1577, the Rawal Askaran of Dungarpur State requested that his daughter be married to Akbar.
In 1582, the Ottoman authorities forced them to return to India.
In 1585, after Muhammad Hakim died, Kabul passed into the hands of Akbar and was officially incorporated as a province of the Mughal Empire.
In 1585, he sent an army to conquer Kashmir in the upper Indus basin after Yousuf Shah, the reigning king of the Shia Chak dynasty, refused to send his son as a hostage to the Mughal court.
In 1586, Akbar negotiated a pact with Abdullah Khan in which the Mughals agreed to remain neutral during the Uzbek invasion of Safavid-held Khorasan.
In 1586, the Mughal governor of Multan tried and failed to secure the capitulation of Mirza Jani Beg, the independent ruler of Thatta in southern Sindh.
In 1593, Akbar began military operations against the Deccan Sultans, who had not submitted to his authority.
In 1593, Akbar received the exiled Safavid prince, Rostam Mirza.
In 1593, he married the daughter of Qazi Isa and the cousin of Najib Khan.
In 1596, three more English ships sailed east but all were lost at sea.
In 1599, Akbar moved his capital back to Agra, where he ruled until his death.
In 1599, a group of prominent merchants and explorers met to discuss a potential East Indies venture under a royal charter.
In 1605, as Akbar lay on his deathbed, young Khurram remained by his bedside and refused to move even after his mother tried to retrieve him.
In 1605, his father succeeded to the throne, after crushing a rebellion by Prince Khusrau.
In 1607, the company decided to build its own ships and leased a yard on the River Thames at Deptford.
In 1611 his father married Nur Jahan, the widowed daughter of a Persian noble.
In 1612, aged 20, Khurram married Mumtaz Mahal, on a date chosen by court astrologers.
In 1615, Khurram presented Kunwar Karan Singh, Amar Singh's heir, to Jahangir.
In 1616, on Khurram's departure to Deccan, Jahangir awarded him the title Shah Sultan Khurram.
In 1617, Khurram was directed to deal with the Lodis in the Deccan to secure the Empire's southern borders and to restore imperial control over the region.
In 1622, Prince Khurram raised an army and marched against his father.
In 1622, Shah Jahan sent Raja Vikramjit, the Governor of Gujarat, to subdue the Kolis of Ahmedabad.
In 1632, Shah Jahan captured the fortress at Daulatabad, Maharashtra and imprisoned Husein Shah of the Nizam Shahi Kingdom of Ahmednagar.
In 1637, Aurangzeb married the Safavid princess Dilras Banu, posthumously known as Rabia-ud-Daurani.
In 1637, however, Shah Jahan decided on complete annexation.
In 1638, Aurangzeb married Nawab Bai, later known as Rahmat al-Nisa.
In 1644, the Mughal prince Aurangzeb was appointed as the viceroy, who then proceeded to become engaged in religious disputes, such as the destruction of a Jain temple in Ahmedabad.
In 1645, he was barred from the court for seven months.
In 1656, a general under Qutb Shahi dynasty named Musa Khan led an army of 12,000 musketeers to attack Aurangzeb, who was besieging Golconda Fort.
In 1657, the Mughal Army used rockets during the siege of Bidar.
In 1658, Aurangzeb arranged his formal coronation in Delhi.
In 1659, Aurangzeb sent his trusted general and maternal uncle Shaista Khan, the Wali in Golconda to recover forts lost to the Maratha rebels.
In 1660 Mir Jumla II, the viceroy of Bengal, was ordered to recover the lost territories.
In 1663, during his visit to Ladakh, Aurangzeb established direct control over that part of the empire and loyal subjects such as Deldan Namgyal agreed to pledge tribute and loyalty.
In 1664, Aurangzeb appointed Shaista Khan subedar (governor) of Bengal.
In 1667, the French East India Company ambassadors Le Gouz and Bebert presented Louis XIV's letter which urged the protection of French merchants from various rebels in the Deccan.
In 1669, Hindu Jats began to organise a rebellion that is believed to have been caused by the re-imposition of jizya and destruction of Hindu temples in Mathura.
In 1672–73, Aurangzeb ordered the resumption of all grants held by Hindus throughout the empire.
In 1675, the Sikh leader Guru Tegh Bahadur was arrested on orders by Aurangzeb, found guilty of blasphemy by a Qadi's court and executed.
In 1686, the East India Company, which had unsuccessfully tried to obtain a firman that would grant them regular trading privileges throughout the Mughal Empire, initiated the Anglo-Mughal War.
In 1687, Aurangzeb led his grand Mughal army against the Deccan Qutbshahi fortress during the siege of Golconda.
In 1689, Aurangzeb's forces captured and executed Sambhaji.
In 1689, a Mughal fleet commanded by Sidi Yaqub attacked Bombay.
In 1689, the second Maratha Chhatrapati (King) Sambhaji was executed by Aurangzeb.
In 1696 Aurangzeb received his envoy, Semyon Malenkiy, and allowed him to conduct free trade.
In 1700, the exchequer of the Emperor Aurangzeb reported an annual revenue of more than £100 million.
In 1701, a combined army of the Sivalik Hill rajas and the Mughals under Wazir Khan attacked Anandpur.
In 1702, Aurangzeb sent Daud Khan Panni, the Mughal Empire's Subhedar of the Carnatic region, to besiege and blockade Fort St. George for more than three months.
In 1705, Guru Gobind Singh sent a letter entitled Zafarnamah, which accused Aurangzeb of cruelty and betraying Islam.
In 1707, Guru Gobind Singh accepted an invitation by Aurangzeb's successor Bahadur Shah I to meet him.
In 1712, another act renewed the status of the company, though the debts were repaid.
In 1715 the Company established a permanent "factory" in Guangzhou (Canton).
In 1716, his army was defeated by the Mughals after he attempted to defend his fort at Gurdas Nangal.
In 1739, the Persian emperor Nader Shah invaded India, defeated the Mughal Emperor Muhammad Shah, and occupied most of Balochistan and the Indus plain.
In 1757, the Law Officers of the Crown delivered the Pratt–Yorke opinion distinguishing overseas territories acquired by right of conquest from those acquired by private treaty.
In 1772, when Warren Hastings was appointed Fort William's first Governor-General, one of his first undertakings was the rapid expansion of the company's army.
In 1783, Ranjit Singh established a crafts colony of Thatheras near Amritsar and encouraged skilled metal crafters from Kashmir to settle in Jandiala Guru.
In 1789, Gurudwara Sis Ganj Sahib was built in Delhi at the place where Guru Tegh Bahadur was beheaded.
In 1789, Ranjit Singh married his first wife Mehtab Kaur, the muklawa happened in 1796.
In 1797, Ranjit Singh besieged Rasulnagar and annexed the Chattha State who had been bitter enemies of Sukerchakia Misl, the ruler Jan Muhammad Chattha was killed in the siege.
In 1798, Zaman Shah army, which Ranjit Singh did not resist.
In 1799, Ranjit Singh moved the capital to Lahore from Gujranwala, where it had been established in 1763 by his grandfather, Charat Singh.
In 1799, Ranjit Singh of Sukerchakia Misl captured Lahore from the Sikh triumvirate which had been ruling it since 1765, and was confirmed on the possession of Lahore by the Durrani ruler, Zaman Shah.
In 1800, the ruler of the Jammu region ceded control of his region to Ranjit Singh.
In 1801, Ranjit Singh proclaimed himself as the "Maharaja of Punjab", and agreed to a formal investiture ceremony, which was carried out by Baba Sahib Singh Bedi – a descendant of Guru Nanak.
In 1801, she gave birth to their son and heir apparent, Kharak Singh.
In 1802, Ranjit Singh married Moran Sarkar, a Muslim nautch girl.
In 1806, the Vellore Mutiny was sparked by new uniform regulations that created resentment amongst both Hindu and Muslim sepoys.
In 1807 she had Sher Singh and Tara Singh.
In 1813, Ranjit Singh's general Dewan Mokham Chand led the Sikh forces against the Afghan forces of Shah Mahmud led by Fateh Khan Barakzai.
In 1818, Darbar's forces led by Kharak Singh and Misr Dewan Chand occupied Multan, killing Nawab Muzaffar Khan and defeating his forces, leading to the end of Afghan influence in Punjab.
In 1823, the Yusufzai Pashtuns fought the army of Ranjit Singh north of the Kabul River.
In 1829, Masson traveled through the princely state of Punjab, gathering useful intelligence for the Company in return for a promise of clemency.
In 1834, Mohammed Azim Khan once again marched towards Peshawar with an army of 25,000 Khattak and Yusafzai tribesmen in the name of jihad, to fight against the maharaja.
In 1835, as his relationship with the British warmed up, he hired a British officer named Foulkes.
In 1835, the Afghans and Sikhs met again at the Standoff at the Khyber Pass; however, it ended without a battle.
In 1837, the Battle of Jamrud, became the last confrontation between the Sikhs led by him and the Afghans, which displayed the extent of the western boundaries of the Sikh Empire.
In 1838 the East India Dock Company merged with the West India Dock Company.
In 1838, Ranjit Singh with his troops marched into Kabul to take part in the victory parade along with the British after restoring Shah Shoja to the Afghan throne at Kabul.
In 1838, he agreed to a treaty with the British viceroy Lord Auckland to restore Shah Shoja to the Afghan throne in Kabul.
In 1839, a major pogrom, called the Allahdad, targeting the local Jews of Mashhad in Qajar Persia had occurred.
In 1842, Masson included his observations of Harappa in the book Narrative of Various Journeys in Baluchistan, Afghanistan, and the Punjab.
In 1849 nearly 13% of all Calcutta deaths were due to smallpox.
In 1854, Berar was annexed, and the state of Oudh was added two years later.
In 1854, Governor-General Lord Dalhousie formulated a plan to construct a network of trunk lines connecting the principal regions of India.
In 1856, the Company introduced a new Enlistment Act making all units in the Bengal Army theoretically liable for overseas service.
In 1857, many Indians had risen in revolt against British rule.
In 1857, the region still contained the highest numbers of both British and Indian troops.
In 1858 the college closed; but in 1862 the buildings reopened as a public school, now Haileybury and Imperial Service College.
In 1860, Grant Medical College became one of the four recognised colleges for teaching courses leading to degrees (alongside Elphinstone College, Deccan College and Government Law College, Mumbai).
In 1861 it was closed, and the site was subsequently redeveloped.
In 1877 Queen Victoria took the title of Empress of India on the advice of Prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli.

In 1893, the Jinnahbhai family moved to Bombay.

In 1905, he travelled to England for that purpose.

In 1907, for the first time, two Indians were appointed to the Council.
In 1907, he had a close friendship with the writer Atiya Fyzee in both Britain and Germany.
In 1908, his factional foe in the Indian National Congress, Bal Gangadhar Tilak, was arrested for sedition.
In 1909 Lord Minto promulgated the Council Act and met with a Muslim delegation led by Aga Khan III, a deal to which Minto agreed.
In 1909, the members of the Muslim League organised a Muslim protest.
In 1911, when the British Raj shifted their colonial capital from Calcutta to Delhi, the nature of the city began changing.
In 1913, Muhammad Ali Jinnah joined the Muslim league.
In 1915, he published his first collection of poetry, the Asrar-i-Khudi اسرارِ خودی (Secrets of the Self) in Persian, for which he was honored with a British knighthood upon its publication.
In 1916, with Jinnah now president of the Muslim League, the two organisations signed the Lucknow Pact, setting quotas for Muslim and Hindu representation in the various provinces.
In 1918, Jinnah married his second wife Rattanbai Petit ("Ruttie"), 24 years his junior.
In 1919, he became the general secretary of the same organisation.
In 1920, however, Jinnah resigned from the Congress when it agreed to follow a campaign of satyagraha, which he regarded as political anarchy.
In 1921, Khan was awarded the Master of Law in Law and Justice, by the college faculty who also conferred on him a Bronze Medallion.
In 1923, both GIPR and EIR were nationalised.
In 1925 the Plague Laboratory in Bombay was renamed the Haffkine Institute.
In 1925, as recognition for his legislative activities, he was offered a knighthood by Lord Reading, who was retiring from the Viceroyalty.
In 1927, a seated male soapstone figure was found in a building with unusually ornamental brickwork and a wall-niche.
In 1927, the British Government, under Conservative Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, undertook a decennial review of Indian policy mandated by the Government of India Act 1919.
In 1930, Jinnah urged Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald and his Viceroy Lord Irwin to convene a Round Table Conferences in London.
In 1930, Khan and Jinnah attended the First Round Table Conference which ended in disaster, leading Jinnah to depart from British India to the UK.
In 1930, Muhammad Iqbal delivered his famous speech in the Allahabad annual session which is commonly regarded as sowing the seeds for the creation of a separate state, later known as Pakistan.
In 1931, Fatima Jinnah joined her brother in England.
In 1932, British Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald accepted Ambedkar's demand for the "Depressed Classes" to have separate representation in the central and provincial legislatures.
In 1932, Khan married for a second time to Begum Ra'ana who was a prominent economist and academic who became an influential figure in the Pakistan movement.
In 1932, he was unanimously elected Deputy President of UP Legislative Council.
In 1933, after returning from a trip to Spain and Afghanistan, Iqbal suffered from a mysterious throat illness.
In 1933, he was officially invited to Afghanistan to join the meetings regarding the establishment of Kabul University.
In 1933, the British colonial government established the first Air Force station in the British Raj near Drigh Road, now called PAF Base Faisal in Karachi.
In 1934, this element of the Royal Indian Air Force (RIAF) was extended to the north for operations in North-West Frontier Province.
In 1935, according to his instructions, Syed Nazeer Niazi initiated and edited the journal, named after Iqbal's poem "Tulu'i Islam".
In 1936, the annual session of the League met in Bombay (now Mumbai).
In 1937, during the 19th session of the Hindu Mahasabha in Ahmedabad, Savarkar declared, "India cannot be assumed today to be a unitarian and homogenous nation.
In 1938, a notable disturbance occurred for religious reasons, but a settlement was reached.
In 1938, they renamed the party National Conference in order to make it representative of all Kashmiris independent of religion.
In 1939, a small representative group of artefacts excavated at the site was transferred to the British Museum by the Director-General of the Archaeological Survey of India.
In 1939, the Congress leaders resigned from all British India government positions to which they had elected.
In 1940, Khan was made the deputy leader of the Muslim League Parliamentary party.
In 1940, Muhammad Ali Jinnah undertook the ideology that religion is the determining factor in defining the nationality of Indian Muslims.
In 1940, the Muslim League, led by Jinnah, passed the Lahore Resolution.
In 1941, Rezaul Karim published a book Pakisthan Examined with the Partition Schemes that firmly rejected the two-nation theory and opposed the division of India.
In 1942, Balraj Madhok arrived in the state as a pracharak of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS).
In 1942, Gandhi called for the Quit India Movement against the United Kingdom.
In 1943, Savarkar publicly expressed his support for Jinnah, stating, "I have no quarrel with Mr Jinnah’s two-nation theory.
In 1943, he entered into his first marriage with his cousin Shireen Amir Begum, from whom he later separated.
In 1943, his marriage was arranged with Shireen Amir Begum.
In 1944–45, Gandhi also began addressing Jinnah as Quaid-e-Azam in his correspondence.
In 1945 and 1946 general and provincial elections were held in India respectively.
In 1945–46, mass elections were held in India and Khan won the Central Legislature election from the Meerut Constituency in the United Provinces.
In 1946 it held a special Gujjar conference intending to appeal to all Muslim Gujjars, and reversed its expulsion of Jahanara Shahnawaz with the hope of appealing to Arain constituencies.
In 1946, he was posted back to British India and was stationed in the North-West Frontier Province.
In 1946, it formed the basis for the decision of Muslim League to struggle for one state [ later named Pakistan] for the Muslims.
In 1946, the Indian independence movement against the British Raj had reached a pivotal stage.
In 1946, the National Conference launched the 'Quit Kashmir' movement, asking the Maharaja to hand the power over to the people.
In 1947, Bhutto was admitted to the University of Southern California to study political science.
In 1947, Khan and his Finance minister Malick Ghulam proposed the idea of Five-Year Plans, by putting the country's economic system on investment and capitalism grounds.
In 1947, Pakistan consisted of West Pakistan (today's Pakistan) and East Pakistan (today's Bangladesh).
In 1947, Pakistan gained independence from the British Raj.
In 1947, he was promoted to brigadier and commanded a brigade in South Waziristan.
In 1947, the princely state of Jammu and Kashmir had a wide range of ethnic and religious communities.
In 1947–48 period, Ali Khan-Jinnah relations was contentious, and the senior military leadership and Jinnah himself became critical of Khan's government.
In 1948, Ben-Gurion of Israel sent a secret courier to Jinnah to establish the diplomatic relations, but Jinnah did not give any response to Ben-Gurion.
In 1948, Eugene Black, then executive director of the World Bank, offered his services to solve the tension over water control.
In 1948, Governor-General Muhammad Ali Jinnah declared that "Urdu, and only Urdu" would be Pakistan's federal language.
In 1948, Jinnah died, and a major problem of religious minorities flared during late 1949 and early 1950.
In 1948, Pakistan established relations with the Soviet Union, and an agreement was announced a month later.
In 1949, Mao Zedong's People's Liberation Army defeated Chiang Kai-shek's United States-backed Kuomintang (KMT) Nationalist Government in China.
In 1949, Pakistan Air Force bombed the Afghan sponsored militant camps in border areas including an Afghan village to curb an unrest led by Ipi Faqir propagating independent Pashtunistan.
In 1949, a Cease-Fire Line Agreement (CFL) was signed and ratified by India, Pakistan and the UN Military Observer Group that delineated the entire CFL.
In 1949, the Indian government obliged Hari Singh to leave Jammu and Kashmir and yield the government to Sheikh Abdullah.
In 1949, the Quaid-e-Azam Memorial Fund (QMF) was established, which received numerous suggestions for the establishment of a memorial to Jinnah.
In 1949–50, the contribution of the industrial sector to the GNP was only 5.8%, of which 4.8% was attributed to small-scale industries.
In 1950, India emerged as a secular republic with a Hindu-majority population.
In 1950, Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan authored the first annexe that would pave a path to the drafting of the Constitution.
In 1950, Sir Mortimer Wheeler identified one large building in Mohenjo-daro as a "Great Granary".
In 1950, severe riots occurred in Barisal and other places in East Pakistan, causing a further exodus of Hindus.
In 1950, the Navy's nationalisation took place when many officers from the air force and army volunteered to join the navy and NCOs gaining commission as an officers.
In 1950, the United States extended an overture to Pakistan by inviting Prime Minister Khan for an official state visit.
In 1951, Khan was assassinated by Sayyid Akbar Babrak, an Afghan national.
In 1951, Prime minister Ali Khan appointed him as the director of the Department of Kashmir and Afghanistan Affairs (DKA).
In 1951, he became the first native commander-in-chief, succeeding General Gracey.
In 1951, the Pakistan government called for appointing native chiefs of the armed forces, but it was not until 1953 that a native navy chief was appointed.
In 1952, Sheikh Abdullah drifted from his previous position of endorsing accession to India to insisting on the self-determination of Kashmiris.
In 1953 Sir Mortimer Wheeler proposed that the invasion of an Indo-European tribe from Central Asia, the "Aryans", caused the decline of the Indus civilisation.
In 1953 at the instigation of religious parties, anti-Ahmadiyya riots erupted, which led to many Ahmadi deaths.
In 1953, Ghulam Mohammad dismissed Prime Minister Nazimuddin, established martial law in Punjab, and imposed governor's rule (direct rule by the central government) in East Pakistan.
In 1953, President Eisenhower implemented Operation Ajax, a covert coup operation to overthrow the Iranian prime minister, Mohammad Mosaddegh.
In 1953, changes in political leadership on both sides shifted the dynamic of the Cold War.
In 1954 the controversial One Unit Program was imposed by the last Pakistan Muslim League (PML) Prime minister Ali Bogra dividing Pakistan on the German geopolitical model.
In 1954, Prime Minister Muhammad Ali Bogra's relations with the military and Governor-General Ghulam Muhammad deteriorated on issues of the economy.
In 1954, an Indian architect was selected to design the mausoleum, but his design could not gain consensus among members of the QMF, and so was dismissed.
In 1954, an Indian architect was selected to design the mausoleum, but was later dismissed.
In 1954, he appointed his own "cabinet of talents".
In 1954, legislative elections were to be held for the Parliament.
In 1955, Pakistan joined the South East Asian Treaty Organization (SEATO) and the Baghdad Pact, later renamed the Central Asian Treaty Organization (CENTO) when Iraq withdrew in 1959.
In 1955, Prime Minister Bogra was dismissed by Governor-General Malik Ghulam Muhammad, and he was succeeded by the new Prime Minister Chaudhry Muhammad Ali as the Defence Minister.
In 1955, Washington secured full German membership of NATO.
In 1955, a Turkish architect was hired, but his plan was rejected as well.
In 1955, at the Bandung Conference in Indonesia, dozens of Third World governments resolved to stay out of the Cold War.
In 1955, in a Cabinet speech he suggested it be given to the Government of Pakistan, but could not gain the sanction of the Cabinet.
In 1955, the United Front named Abu Hussain Sarkar as the Chief Minister of the State and he ruled the state in two non-consecutive terms until 1958, when martial law was imposed.
In 1956 the Constituent Assembly of Pakistan approved a constitution that ended Pakistan's status as an independent Dominion of the British Empire, to create an Islamic Republic of Pakistan.
In 1956, Pakistani Prime Minister Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy and Chinese Premier Zhou Enlai signed the Treaty of Friendship Between China and Pakistan, marking closer bilateral ties.
In 1956, he denounced Joseph Stalin and proceeded to ease controls over the party and society (de-Stalinization).
In 1956, he left Turkey and returned to Pakistan in 1957 where he attended Saint Patrick's School in Karachi and was accepted at the Forman Christian College University in Lahore.
In 1956, the Pakistan Army decided to adopt a round shape that reflected Islamic Heritage.
In 1956–58, a scientific team led by the Geological Survey of India recorded its findings publicly including information about the Siachen and other glaciers.
In 1957 Pakistan permitted a British expedition under Eric Shipton to approach the Siachen glacier through the Bilafond La, and recce Saltoro Kangri.
In 1957 the Pakistan Air Force received 100 American-built F-86 Sabres under the U.S. aid programme.
In 1957 the president used his considerable influence to oust Suhrawardy from the office of prime minister.
In 1957 thirty-six-year-old Air Marshal Asghar Khan became the Pakistan Air Force's first native commander-in-chief.
In 1957, Bhutto became the youngest member of Pakistan's delegation to the United Nations.
In 1957, Polish foreign minister Adam Rapacki proposed the Rapacki Plan for a nuclear free zone in central Europe.
In 1957, President Mirza promoted him from acting full general to the substantive rank of full general.
In 1957, the Government of Pakistan held an international competition to design a new mausoleum for Jinnah.
In 1958, President Iskandar Mirza enacted martial law as part of a military coup by the Pakistan Army's chief Ayub Khan.
In 1958, President Mirza accepted the resignation of Vice-Admiral M.S.
In 1959, the International Labour Organization (ILO) published a report stating that from 1951 to 1956, a total of 650,000 Muslims from India relocated to West Pakistan.
In 1959, the country began the construction of its new capital city.
In 1960, Ayub Khan granted permission for the United States to fly its first spy missions to the Soviet Union from the Peshawar Air Base, which had been recently upgraded with American funds.
In 1960, Lower Tippera was renamed Comilla.
In 1960, President Ayub, together with Prime Minister Nehru, signed the Indus Waters Treaty brokered by the World Bank.
In 1960, a bureaucrat named Ishrat Hussain Usmani succeeded Ahmad as chairman of the PAEC.
In 1960s Pakistan received 700 million dollars of military aid from United States, by signing a defense agreement in 1954, which significantly modernized Pakistan's military equipment.
In 1961 the Pakistani space program was launched and the nuclear power program was continued.
In 1961, Khan paid his first visit to the United States as head of state.
In 1961, Soviet-allied East Germany constructed the Berlin Wall to prevent the citizens of East Berlin from fleeing to West Berlin, at the time part of United States-allied West Germany.
In 1961, at the age of 18, Musharraf entered the Pakistan Military Academy at Kakul.
In 1961–62, Ayub paid a state visit to the United Kingdom.
In 1962, China invaded and fought a war with India along the disputed Indo-Chinese border, including in Indian administered-Ladakh, marking their entry to the Kashmir conflict.
In 1962, Pakistan had witnessed the Sino-Indian War, with China emerging victorious.
In 1962, after India was defeated by China, Ayub Khan disguised a few thousand soldiers as guerillas and sent them to Indian Kashmir to incite the people to rebel.
In 1962, as territorial differences escalated between India and China, Beijing considered staging an invasion in northern Indian territories.
In 1962, the Space Research Commission launched the first solid-fuel rocket, Rehbar-I, built with close interaction with the U.S. NASA.
In 1962, the second set of the Constitution completely dissolved the office of prime minister as all powers were transferred to the president of Pakistan.
In 1962, troops from the People's Republic of China and India clashed in territory claimed by both.
In 1963, Ayub signed the historic Sino-Pakistan Frontier Agreement with China despite US opposition.
In 1964 the Pakistani Armed Forces quelled a suspected pro-communist revolt in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, West Pakistan, allegedly supported by communist Afghanistan.
In 1964, Khrushchev's Kremlin colleagues managed to oust him, but allowed him a peaceful retirement.
In 1964, President Ayub Khan was confident in his apparent popularity and saw the deep divisions within the political opposition which ultimately led him to announce presidential elections in 1965.
In 1964, the Pakistan Army engaged with the Indian Army in several skirmishes, and clandestine operations began.
In 1964, the Soviet Union and its satellite states broke off relations with Beijing over ideological differences, with only Albania and Pakistan supporting the People's Republic of China.
In 1965, Bhutto advocated for Salam, successfully appointing him as the head of Pakistan's delegation at the IAEA, and assisted Salam in lobbying for nuclear power plants.
In 1965, Bhutto received information from his friend Munir Ahmad Khan about the status of India's nuclear program.
In 1965, General Ayub Khan entered the presidential race as the Convention Muslim League's candidate to counter the opposition candidate Fatima Jinnah.
In 1965, Pakistan attempted to infiltrate Indian-administered Kashmir to precipitate an insurgency there, resulting in another war fought by the two countries over the region.
In 1965, Pakistan implemented the Kaptai Dam hydroelectric project in the southeastern part of East Pakistan with American assistance.
In 1965, Science Advisor to the Government Abdus Salam traveled to United States to sign an agreement with the government of United States to provide a research reactor in Rawalpindi.
In 1965, after Pakistan went ahead with its strategic infiltration mission in Kashmir codenamed Operation Gibraltar, India declared full-scale war against Pakistan.
In 1965, assuming that a weakened Indian Military would not respond, Pakistan chose to send in "mujahideens" and Pakistan Army regulars into the Indian-controlled part of Jammu and Kashmir.
In 1965, it decided that the conditions were ripe for a successful guerilla war in Kashmir.
In 1966 the Awami League led by Sheikh Mujibur Rahman demanded provisional autonomy at the Round Table Conference held by Ayub Khan; this was forcefully rejected by Bhutto.
In 1966 the Indian opposition leader Jayaprakash wrote to Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi that India rules Kashmir by force.
In 1966, Awami League leader Sheikh Mujibur Rahman announced the six-point movement in Lahore.
In 1966, Mujib demanded that separate foreign exchange accounts be kept and that separate trade offices be opened overseas.
In 1966, the Pakistan Navy established its own special operations force, the Navy Special Service Group (Navy SSG) after the recommendations from the United States Navy.
In 1966–1967, it would rise to 17% and by 1970–1971 it would rise to 25% of its revenue.
In 1966–67, Ayub wrestled with the United States' attempt to dictate Pakistan's foreign policy, while he strengthened relations with the Soviet Union and China.
In 1967 a Socialist convention, attended by the country's leftist philosophers and notable thinkers, took place in Lahore.
In 1967, Bhutto formed People's Party of Pakistan and tapped a wave of anti-Ayub Khan movement in both West and East Pakistan.
In 1967, Bhutto formed the Pakistan People's Party (PPP) and embarked on a nationwide tour where he attacked the Ayub administration's economic, religious, and social policies.
In 1967, India's nuclear program was aimed at the development of nuclear weapons, with Indira Gandhi overseeing the development of the weapons.
In 1967, a team of Pakistani scientists, under Rafi Muhammad Chaudhry, produced the first batch of radioisotopes at the Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology.
In 1967, disapproval of price hikes of food prompted demonstrations across the country led by Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.
In 1967, the PPP tapped a wave of anger against Ayub Khan and successfully called for major labour strikes in the country.
In 1968, Muhajirs from East Pakistan started Muhjairland movement for a separated province.
In 1968, a period of political liberalization took place in Czechoslovakia called the Prague Spring.
In 1968, his administration celebrated the so-called "Decade of Development" when the mass protests erupted all over the country due to an increasingly greater divide between the rich and the poor.
In 1968, research on theoretical physics had begun at the newly created Institute of Physics (IP).
In 1969 he raised the 9th Armoured Brigade in Kharian as the first Brigade Commander of the unit; the brigade is currently stationed in Gujranwala under the 6th Armoured Division.
In 1969, Ayub Khan opened negotiations with the opposition parties in what was termed as a "Round Table Conference" where he held talks with all major opposition parties.
In 1969, Raziuddin Siddiqui established Einstein's Physics Group (EPG) and carried out experiments on general relativity and quantum mechanics.
In 1969, South Yemen, which was under a communist regime and a strong ally of the USSR, attacked and captured Mount Vadiya inside the province of Sharoora in Saudi Arabia.
In 1969, two new districts were created with Tangail separated from Mymensingh and Patuakhali from Bakerganj.
In 1970, Bhutto advised Japan not to be a party to NPT, but Japan signed it but later regretted not being properly progressed.
In 1970, King Hussein of Jordan decided to remove the PLO from Jordan by force after a series of terrorist acts attributed to the PLO, which undermined Jordanian sovereignty.
In 1970, Liaquat Ali Khan and Fatima Jinnah's joint affidavit that Jinnah was Shia was rejected.
In 1970, Yahya Khan organised Pakistan's first federal general election.
In 1970–71, the expenditure on defence accounted for 32% or 55.66% of the total government expenditure.
In 1971, East Pakistan became the newly independent state Bangladesh, which means "country of Bengal" or "country of Bengalis" or "land of Bengalis" in the Bengali language.
In 1971, India gained military and political momentum over Pakistan, after their success in the Indo-Pakistani war of 1971.
In 1971, however, the Bangladesh Liberation War resulted in the dissolution of East Pakistan, which seceded from West Pakistan to become present-day Bangladesh.
In 1971, when he assumed control, Pakistan was in disarray after a brutal civil war.
In 1971, while she was at Harvard, Zulfikar invited her to join him in New York City, where he was involved in a United Nations Security Council meeting on that year's Indo-Pakistani War.
In 1971–72, Pakistan ended its alliance with the United States after the East-Pakistan war in which East Pakistan successfully seceded with the aid of India.
In 1972 the country's top intelligence services provided an assessment on the Indian nuclear program, concluding that: "India was close to developing a nuclear weapon under its nuclear programme".
In 1972, Benazir accompanied her father to the India-Pakistan Summit in Simla as a replacement for her mother, who was ill.
In 1972, Bhutto initially attempted to forge friendly ties with Afghanistan, but these efforts were rebuffed in 1973.
In 1972, the US initiated diplomatic contacts with China and the US and USSR signed a series of treaties limiting their nuclear arsenals during a period known as détente.
In 1972, the government initially provided old age benefits through group insurance, enhanced compensation rates, and gratuity.
In 1973, Bhutto appointed Raziuddin Siddiqui as Technical member of Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission, and made him responsible for the preparation of its charter.
In 1973, Iraq provided the Balochs with conventional arms, and it opened an office for the Baluchistan Liberation Front (BLF) in Baghdad.
In 1973, Nixon announced his administration was committed to seeking most favored nation trade status with the USSR, which was challenged by Congress in the Jackson-Vanik Amendment.
In 1973, during the Yom Kippur War, Pakistan's relations with the Arab world represented a watershed.
In 1974 Bhutto succumbed to increasing pressure from religious parties and encouraged Parliament to declare adherents of Ahmadiyya to be non-Muslims.
In 1974, Bhutto adopted the recommendation from Hamoodur Rehman Commission, and disbanded the "Commander-in-Chief" title as the head of the Pakistan Armed Forces.
In 1974, Bhutto and his Foreign Minister Aziz Ahmed brought a U.N. resolution, recommending the establishment of a nuclear-weapon-free zone in South Asia.
In 1974, Bhutto appointed the civil engineer Mubashir Hassan as the head of the committee.
In 1974, Bhutto hosted the second Organisation of the Islamic Conference (OIC) in 1974 where he delegated and invited leaders from the Muslim world to Lahore, Punjab Province of Pakistan.
In 1974, Bhutto initiated a more aggressive diplomatic offensive on the United States and the Western world over nuclear issues.
In 1974, Bhutto maintained that foreign companies and industries in Pakistan were exempt from nationalisation policies, and his government would welcome foreign investment to establish factories.
In 1974, Bhutto's trusted Science Advisor Abdus Salam left Pakistan when Parliament declared Ahmadis as non-Muslims.
In 1974, Bhutto, as prime minister, visited the Soviet Union.
In 1974, India carried out a nuclear test, codenamed Smiling Buddha, near Pakistan's eastern border.
In 1974, pressured by other Muslim nations, Pakistan eventually recognised Bangladesh as Mujib stated he would only go to the OIC conference in Lahore if Pakistan recognised Bangladesh.
In 1974, she flew to Lahore to accompany her father at the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation's summit.
In 1974, the Parliament of Pakistan gave approval of 1973 Constitution.
In 1974, the State Subject law was officially abolished in Gilgit Baltistan, which allowed any Pakistani to settle and buy land.
In 1974, with Abdus Salam's assistance, Bhutto authorised the International Nathiagali Summer College on Contemporary Physics (INSC) at Nathiagali.
In 1974, with India carried out the test of nuclear weapons near the Pakistan's eastern border, codename Smiling Buddha, Bhutto sought the United States to impose economic sanctions in India.
In 1975, Abdul Qadeer Khan met with Bhutto in private and requested a military department to supervise his work rather than Hassan.
In 1975, Bhutto acknowledged the challenges and shortcomings faced by college students in many existing hostels.
In 1976 an organization called Special Development Works (SDW) was created within the Pakistan Army, directly under the Chief of the Army Staff (Pakistan) (COAS).
In 1976, Zia was elevated to the rank of general and was appointed as chief of the army staff by Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, succeeding Tikka Khan.
In 1976, during a secret mission, Henry Kissinger threatened Bhutto and his colleagues.
In 1976, the Navy moved towards successfully acquiring the military computers from the British firm, the Ferranti, to increase its defence's for its coastlines.
In 1976, the Supplementary Report was submitted, which was the comprehensive report compiled together with the First Report; this report was also marked as classified.
In 1977 general elections were held in which the Peoples Party were victorious.
In 1977, Bhutto was arrested by his appointed army chief Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq, who declared martial law and assumed presidency in 1978.
In 1977, Bhutto was overthrown in a military coup led by Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq.
In 1977, Prime minister Bhutto established a military committee to maintain military administrative leadership in project.
In 1977, after Zia took over the government, Libya's connection with Project-706 was immediately cut, resulting in Libyan scientists leaving Pakistan.
In 1977, she was elected President of the Oxford Union debating society, the first Asian woman to hold that post.
In 1977, the PAEC's Theoretical Physics Group had completed the design of the first fission weapon, and KRL scientists succeeded in electromagnetic isotope separation of Uranium fissile isotopes.
In 1978 this expedition climbed Teram Kangri II, claiming it as a first ascent in a typical "oropolitical" riposte.
In 1978, India gave citizenship to 55,000 Pakistani Hindus.
In 1978, the PAEC had eliminated the MLIS method as secondary process due to its difficulty and complexity.
In 1979, a group of Pakistani students burned the American embassy in Islamabad to the ground, as a reaction to the Grand Mosque Seizure, citing U.S. involvement.
In 1979, following the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, Zia adopted an anti-Soviet stance and aided the Afghan mujahideen.
In 1979, the France offered to sell their Agosta-70A-class submarine and was immediately acquired which were commissioned as Hurmat and Hashmat.
In 1979, the toppling of US-allied governments in Iran and Nicaragua and the outbreak of the Soviet–Afghan War again raised tensions.
In 1979, when Zia departed for Saudi Arabia, Justice Anwar-ul-Haq served as interim president of Pakistan.
In 1980, Ronald Reagan won the 1980 presidential election, vowing to increase military spending and confront the Soviets everywhere.
In 1981, Nawaz joined the Punjab Advisory Council under Khan.
In 1981, Zia contracted with China when he sent weapon-grade uranium to China and also built the centrifuge laboratory which increasingly enhanced the Chinese nuclear programme.
In 1981, interest payments were replaced by profit and loss sharing accounts; however, profit and loss sharing was simply viewed as another name for the practice of interest .
In 1981, the reactor went critical under Iqbal Hussain Qureshi.
In 1982 the small Ahmadiyya religious minority were prohibited from saying or implying they were Muslims.
In 1982, Khan became captain of the Pakistan national cricket team.
In 1982, Reagan tried to cut off Moscow's access to hard currency by impeding its proposed gas line to Western Europe.
In 1982, the MLIS method was used to separate plutonium isotopes at the Neutron Activation Analysis Laboratory of the PINSTECH.
In 1983, Bhutto's decision was posthumously vindicated when PAEC conducted a cold test near Kirana Hills, evidently made from non-fissioned plutonium.
In 1983, Pakistan achieved a major milestone in its efforts after it covertly performed a series of non-fission tests, codenamed Kirana-I.
In 1983, he was named a Wisden Cricketer of the Year.
In 1983, learned men of Kashmiri politics testified that Kashmiris had always wanted to be independent.
In 1983, the PCB became one of the founding members of the ACC.
In 1983, when the first batch of F-16s reached Pakistan, ACM Shamim informed Zia of the PAF's capability to respond to an attack on the nuclear research facilities at Kahuta.
In 1984 a high court bench reversed the 1976 verdict and maintained that "the Quaid was definitely not a Shia", which suggested that Jinnah was Sunni.
In 1984, India gained Siachen after launching a short military action.
In 1984, Zia held a referendum asking for support for his religious programme; he received overwhelming support.
In 1985, Khan nominated Nawaz as Chief Minister of Punjab, against the wishes of Prime Minister Muhammad Khan Junejo.
In 1986, Shah decided to construct a mosque within the premises of an ancient Hindu temple inside the New Civil Secretariat area in Jammu to be made available to the Muslim employees for 'Namaz'.
In 1987, Khan led Pakistan to its first Test series win in India, followed by its first series victory in England the same year.
In 1987, President Zia-ul-Haq offered Khan a post in the Pakistan Muslim League (PML), which he declined.
In 1987, Zia launched the clandestine aerospace project, the Integrated Missile Research Program under General Anwar Shamim in 1985, and later under Lieutenant-General Talat Masood in 1987.
In 1987, he became a brigade commander of a new brigade of the SSG near Siachen Glacier.
In 1987, the KSEW began developing submarine technology and rebuilding the submarine base near Port Qasim.
In 1988, Bhutto published her autobiography, sub-titled Daughter of the East in its British edition and Daughter of Destiny in the United States.
In 1988, General Zia dismissed the government of Junejo and called for new elections.
In 1988, a mutual understanding was reached between the two countries in which each pledged not to attack nuclear facilities.
In 1988, he led Pakistan on a successful West Indies tour.
In 1988, the USSR abandoned its war in Afghanistan and began to withdraw its forces.
In 1989, Benazir Bhutto made a quick visit in the U.S. asking U.S. to stop financing the Afghan mujahideen to President George H. W. Bush, which she marked "America's Frankenstein".
In 1989, Bhutto ordered a military intervention in Afghanistan, which failed, leading her to dismiss the directors of the intelligence services.
In 1989, Soviet forces withdrew from Afghanistan without achieving their objectives.
In 1989, a widespread popular and armed insurgency started in Kashmir.
In 1989, an armed insurgency erupted against Indian rule in Indian-administered Kashmir Valley, after years of political disenfranchisement and alienation, with logistical support from Pakistan.
In 1989, she attended the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Kuala Lumpur, where Pakistan was re-admitted to the Commonwealth of Nations.
In 1989, the Russian SFSR convened a newly elected Congress of People's Deputies.
In 1989, the communist governments in Poland and Hungary became the first to negotiate the organization of competitive elections.
In 1990, Bhutto gave birth to her first daughter, Bakhtawar.
In 1990, the Marines were recommissioned under Commander M. Obaidullah.
In 1991, the Russian Federation became the Soviet Union's successor state, while many of the other republics emerged as fully independent post-Soviet states.
In 1991–93, he secured a two-star promotion, elevating him to the rank of major general and held the command of 40th Division as its GOC, stationed in Okara Military District in Punjab Province.
In 1992, Pakistan became an associate member of the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research.
In 1993, Bhutto declared that her family burial ground would be converted into an official mausoleum and would undergo significant expansion.
In 1993, Nawaz established the Institute of Nuclear Engineering (INE) to promote his policy for the peaceful use of nuclear energy.
In 1993, he was appointed tourism ambassador in the caretaker government of Moeenuddin Ahmad Qureshi for three months until it was dissolved.
In 1993–95, Major-General Musharraf worked closely with the Chief of Army Staff as Director-General of Pakistan Army's Directorate General for the Military Operations (DGMO).
In 1994 and 1995 they made a "train march" from Karachi to Peshawar, making critical speeches to huge crowds.
In 1994 she successfully approached France for the transfer of Air-independent propulsion technology.
In 1994, the NGO International Commission of Jurists sent a fact finding mission to Kashmir.
In 1995, Benazir Bhutto made another state visit to the United States and held talks with U.S. president Bill Clinton.
In 1995, Benazir also appointed Admiral Mansurul Haq as the Chief of Naval Staff, as the Admiral had personal contacts with the Benazir's family.
In 1995, Poolster-class PNS Moawin was subjected to a serious fire accident that claimed valuable life during the refitting of the vessel in Karachi.
In 1995, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, fearing a military coup that could make him Prime Minister, responded with punitive measures.
In 1995, Zardari purchased a fifteen-bedroom country house at Rockwood in Surrey, southern England; to hide evidence of ownership, he obtained the property through companies based in the Isle of Man.
In 1995, the ISI reported to Bhutto that Narasimha Rao had authorised nuclear tests and that they could be conducted at any minute.
In 1996, Asghar Khan filed a lawsuit challenging the results of the 1990 elections, following the discovery of the Mehran bank scandal.
In 1996, Benazir Bhutto met with Japanese officials and warned India about conducting nuclear tests.
In 1996, The Wall Street Journal said he used populist rhetoric, blending anti-elite messages with religious appeals.
In 1996, Transparency International ranked Pakistan as the world's second most corrupt country.
In 1996, seven weeks after this incident, Benazir Bhutto's government was dismissed by her own hand-picked president on charges of Murtaza Bhutto's death.
In 1997, Nawaz signed a trilateral free trade agreement with Malaysia and Singapore, which was followed by collaboration in defence.
In 1997, high-level Indo-Pakistan talks resumed after a three-year pause.
In 1998, India and Pakistan made an agreement recognising the principle of building an environment of peace and security and resolving all bilateral conflicts.
In 1998, Iran and Afghanistan were on the verge of war over the assassination of Iranian diplomats.
In 1998, Switzerland issued a request for the arrest of Bhutto on suspicion of money laundering.
In 1999, Benazir leaked the information that Nawaz Sharif would be deposed that there is (nothing) that Americans want to support Nawaz Sharif or the democracy in Pakistan.
In 1999, Nawaz signed the executive decree, declaring 28 May as the National Science Day in Pakistan.
In 1999, an armed conflict between the two countries broke out again in Kargil with no effect on the status quo.
In 1999, an extended period of intense border-skirmishing with India, the Kargil War, resulted in a massive redeployment of forces in Kashmir.
In 1999, industrial production grew by 3.9 percent.
In 1999, the Pakistan Army soldiers secretly crossed the Line of Control (LoC) and infiltrated in Kargil on the direct orders issues by General Musharraf, bringing the two nations at the brink of war.
In 2000 Kamran Atif, an alleged member of Harkat-ul Mujahideen al-Alami, tried to assassinate Musharraf.
In 2000 the government issued a nationwide amnesty to the political workers of liberal parties, sidelining the conservatives and leftists in the country.
In 2000, the Supreme Court accepted arguments that the coup was a "violation of the constitution".
In 2000, the excerpts of the Supplementary Report were leaked to a political correspondent of Pakistan's Dawn, which the Dawn published together with India Today.
In 2001, General Musharraf issued the executive decree, of which, President Tarar was of the view that such decree was unconstitutional and illegal.
In 2001, Musharraf got on stage with the rock music band, Junoon, and sang the national song with the band.
In 2001, Musharraf issued the executive decree and eventually forced President Rafiq Tarar to resign in order for Musharraf to assume the presidency.
In 2001, Musharraf seized the presidency through a legal order and a referendum but was constitutionally confirmed in this capacity in 2004.
In 2001, US President George W. Bush pressured the government into joining the US the war on terror.
In 2001, a summit was called in Agra; Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf turned up to meet Indian Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee.
In 2001, the Navy took serious consideration of deploying the nuclear weapons on its submarines although none of the nuclear weapons were ever deployed in the submarines.
In 2001, the PML(N) and its rival PPP reached a compromised when the formed democracy restoration alliance in a view to oust President Musharraf.
In 2002, Admiral Bokhari quoted that: he knew about General Musharraf's plans to topple [Prime Minister] Nawaz Sharif and did not want to be part of these "Dirty Games".
In 2002, Musharraf amended the constitution to ban anyone serving more than two terms as prime minister, thus disqualifying both Bhutto and Sharif, whom he called "useless politicians".
In 2002, the Navy filed a civil lawsuit to refrain the Bahria Town using its name for profiteering – the lawsuit was eventually settled in civil court in favour of Navy in 2018.
In 2003, the US officially forgave US$1 billion in Pakistani debt in a ceremony in Pakistan in turn for Pakistan joining the US "war on terror".
In 2003, the nephew of the Quaid-i-Azam, Akbar Pirbhai, re-ignited the controversy by suggesting that Fatima Jinnah's death in 1967 was an assassination by the Ayub Khan establishment.
In 2003, the service uniforms for each major service branch were revised and orders were made to issue new uniforms roughly based on the American military.
In 2003–04, there were several proposals made for acquiring the vintage aircraft carriers but the Navy itself had dismissed the idea since the country has not aspired to have an aircraft capability.
In 2004, Access Group International announced plans to invest $1 billion over the next 5 years in solar cell manufacture and wind farms.
In 2004, Musharraf began a series of talks with India to resolve the Kashmir dispute on the sidelines of the 12th SAARC summit in Islamabad.
In 2004, a UK court ruled that Rockwood Estate in Surrey—which Zardari owned, despite his repeated denials—should be sold and the proceeds given to the Pakistani state, who were the rightful owners.
In 2004, a road in Pakistani capital Islamabad leading to the Diplomatic Enclave was named "Zhou Enlai Road".
In 2004, during the Indian cricket team's tour of Pakistan, he appeared as a commentator on TEN Sports' live show, Straight Drive.
In 2004, the incomplete project was passed on to Pakistan Army's X Corps and after facing delays, it finally opened in 2006.
In 2004, the site was added to the tentative list for UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
In 2004, the two countries also agreed upon decreasing the number of troops present in the region.
In 2005 it was reported that two batches in the Air Force Academy's flying wing contained 10 women, with many more in the engineering and aerospace wings.
In 2005, General Musharraf, as well as other Pakistani leaders, sought to resolve the Kashmir issue through the Chenab formula road map.
In 2005, Pakistan's information minister, Sheikh Rashid, was alleged to have run a terrorist training camp in 1990 in N.W.
In 2005, a controversial amusement park scheme at the site was abandoned when builders unearthed many archaeological artefacts during the early stages of building work.
In 2005, a corruption case was filed in the National Accountability Bureau (NAB) against then managing director Syed Muhammad Amjad who was involved in the corruption.
In 2005, the Bugti clan attacked a gas field in Balochistan, after Dr. Shazia was raped at that location.
In 2005, the Navy deployed the PNS Badr (D-184) to help assists the relief efforts for the earthquake that struck the northern part of the country in October 2005.
In 2006 Al-Qaeda claim they have established a wing in Kashmir, which worried the Indian government.
In 2006, Human Rights Watch accused ISI and the military of systemic torture with the purpose of "punishing" errant politicians, political activists and journalists in Azad Kashmir.
In 2006, King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia visited Pakistan for the first time as King.
In 2006, a "Friends Without Borders" scheme began with the help of two British tourists.
In 2006, the Pakistani National Accountability Bureau (NAB) accused Bhutto, Malik and Ali Jaffery of owning Petrofine.
In 2006, while visiting his children in London, he also worked with the Lord's Taverners cricket charity.
In 2007 Sharif made a daring attempt to return from exile but was refrained from landing at Islamabad Airport.
In 2007, Der Spiegel compared him to Franz Beckenbauer for his popularity and influence in Pakistan.
In 2007, Nawaz Sharif with his family, accompanied by his daughter, returned to Pakistan with thousands of his supporters receiving Sharif family.
In 2007, President Musharraf eventually imposed another martial law by having suspended the populist Chief Justice IM Chaudhry, leveling charges of corruption and misconduct.
In 2007, a group of retired British soldiers and civilians, some of them descendants of British soldiers who died in the conflict, attempted to visit the site of the Siege of Lucknow.
In 2007, he violated the agreement and attempted to return to Pakistan but was deported.
In 2007, mass anti-Musharraf protests broke out in what was known as the Lawyers' Movement.
In 2007, the President of India, Abdul Kalam became the first head of state to visit the area.
In 2008, 85 security personnel died compared to 613 in 2001, while 102 militants were killed.
In 2008, Asif Ali Zardari was elected president.
In 2008, NSA Director Mike McConnell confronted ISI Director Ahmad Shuja Pasha, claiming that the ISI was tipping off jihadists so that they could escape in advance of American attacks against them.
In 2008, Pakistan had purchased military equipment from China for an improved quality of defence arsenal and force to fight the constant attack from foreign militants.
In 2008, Sharif spearheaded the judicial activism in order to protest the suspension of Chief Justice I.M.
In 2008, authorities said that 43,000 people have been killed in the violence.
In 2008, the death toll from the last 20 years was estimated by Indian authorities to be over 47,000.
In 2009, Pakistan was the single largest contributor of UN peacekeeping forces, with more than 11,000 Pakistani military personnel serving in UN peacekeeping operations worldwide.
In 2009, he was inducted into the ICC Cricket Hall of Fame.
In 2009, protests started over the alleged rape and murder of two young women in Shopian in South Kashmir.
In 2009, the Pakistani government implemented an autonomy package for Gilgit-Baltistan, which entails rights similar to those of Pakistan's other provinces.
In 2009, the UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon established a three-person team to lead the investigation comprising the Chilean Heraldo Muñoz, Irish Peter FitzGerald, and Indonesian Marzuki Darusman.
In 2009, the issue of establishing the International Crimes Tribunal began to take public support.
In 2009–11, Gillani, under pressure from the public and co-operating with the United States, ordered the armed forces to launch military campaigns against Taliban forces in the north-west of Pakistan.
In 2010, a corruption scandal was unearthed that involved two Pakistan Army generals, (Maj Gen Khalid Zaheer Akhtar and Lt Gen Muhammad Afzal), and caused a loss of Rs.
In 2010, armed forces personnel donated one day of salary for their flood-effected brethren.
In 2010, the Awami League's government decided to set up a tribunal to prosecute the people involved in alleged war crimes and those who collaborated with Pakistan.
In 2010, the Navy coordinated one of its largest relief operations during the nationwide flash floods, with Navy divers rescuing and evacuating more than 352,291 people in August 2010.
In 2010, the XVIII Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan was passed to reverse the XVII amendment; it returned the country to being a parliamentary democratic republic.
In 2010, the air force procured at least 18 newly built F-16C/D Block 52s under the Peace Gate-II[clarification needed] by the United States.
In 2010, with the support of its intelligence agencies, Pakistan again 'boosted' Kashmir militants, and recruitment of mujahideen in the Pakistani state of Punjab has increased.
In 2011 China Kingho Group cancelled a $19 billion mining deal because of security concerns.
In 2011 steps were taken by Gillani to block all major NATO supply lines after a border skirmish between NATO and Pakistan.
In 2011, 24 Indian soldiers died on the Siachen glacier from the climate and accidents.
In 2011, Nawaz's assets were worth Rs 166 million, which increased to Rs 1.82 billion by 2013.
In 2011, he also lectured at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace on politics and racism where he also authored and published a paper with George Perkvich.
In 2011, responsibility for the preservation of the site was transferred to the government of Sindh.
In 2011, the Navy commissioned two more small tankers/utility ships (STUS) —PNS Madadgar and PNS Rasadgar —to support the logistics and marine operations in the open sea.
In 2011, the state humans right commission said it had evidence that 2,156 bodies had been buried in 40 graves over the last 20 years.
In 2012, Musharraf's senior officer and retired major-general Abdul Majeed Malik maintained that Kargil was a "total disaster" and bitterly criticised General Musharraf.
In 2012, Pakistani archaeologists warned that, without improved conservation measures, the site could disappear by 2030.
In 2012, a total of 12 Indian soldiers died of hostile weather conditions.
In 2012, only 10% of Americans expressed trust in Pakistan.
In 2013, 10 Indian soldiers died due to weather conditions.
In 2013, Khan proposed secret talks between India and Pakistan to resolve the Kashmir issue, saying open negotiations risk being subverted by vested interests on both sides.
In 2013, this figure increased to 90% of Pakistanis having a favourable view of China.
In 2014, Canadian rock band Nickelback released the politically themed single "Edge of a Revolution", featuring a brief clip of a PTI rally with party flags and a poster of him.
In 2014, Musharraf was declared an "absconder" in the Bugti and Bhutto assassination cases by virtue of moving to Dubai due to failing health.
In 2014, during the visit of Russian Defence Minister Sergey Shoygu, Pakistan and Russia signed an agreement on military cooperation.
In 2014, the estimates established the Navy's manpower strength at 30,700 active duty personnel.

Iqbal's thoughts in his work primarily focus on the spiritual direction and development of human society, centered around experiences from his travels and stays in Western Europe and the Middle East.

Mohenjo-daro (/moʊˌhɛndʒoʊ ˈdɑːroʊ/; Sindhi: موهن جو دڙو‎, lit.
Mohenjo-daro had no series of city walls, but was fortified with guard towers to the west of the main settlement, and defensive fortifications to the south.
Mohenjo-daro has a hot desert climate (Köppen climate classification BWh) with extremely hot summers and mild winters.
Mohenjo-daro has a planned layout with rectilinear buildings arranged on a grid plan.
Mohenjo-daro is located off the right (west) bank of the lower[a] Indus river in Larkana District, Sindh, Pakistan.
Mohenjo-daro may also have been a point of diffusion for the clade of the domesticated chicken found in Africa, Western Asia, Europe and the Americas.
Mohenjo-daro was built in the 26th century BCE.
Mohenjo-daro was the most advanced city of its time, with remarkably sophisticated civil engineering and urban planning.
Mohenjo-daro, the modern name for the site, has been interpreted as "Mound of the Dead" in Sindhi.

Mughal India had a large shipbuilding industry, which was also largely centred in the Bengal province.
Mughal India was now the world's largest economy, responsible for almost a quarter of global production, as well as a sophisticated customs and taxation system within the empire.
Mughal India was one of the three Islamic gunpowder empires, along with the Ottoman Empire and Safavid Persia.

Saraiki (سرائیکی) is an Indo Aryan language of the Lahnda group spoken in central and southeastern Pakistan, primarily in the southern part of the province of Punjab.
Saraiki is spoken by approximately 26 million people in Pakistan, ranging across southern Punjab, southern Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, and border regions of northern Sindh and eastern Balochistan.
Saraiki is to a high degree mutually intelligible with Standard Punjabi and is coshares with it a large portion of its vocabulary and morphology.

Shah Jahan I[a] (Shahab-ud-Din Muhammad Khurram; 5 January 1592 – 22 January 1666), also called Shah Jahan the Magnificent, was the fifth Mughal Emperor from 1628 until his deposition in 1658.
Shah Jahan also expanded the Mughal Empire to the west beyond the Khyber Pass to Ghazna and Kandahar.

Shah Jahan continued striking coins in three metals: gold (mohur), silver (rupee) and copper (dam).

Shah Jahan gave orders in 1631 to Qasim Khan, the Mughal viceroy of Bengal, to drive out the Portuguese from their trading post at Port Hoogly.

Shah Jahan personally owned the royal treasury, and several precious stones, such as the Kohinoor.

The British Raj (/rɑːdʒ/ RAHJ; from Hindustani rāj, 'reign', 'rule' or 'government') was the rule of the British Crown on the Indian subcontinent, lasting from 1858 to 1947.
The British Raj extended over almost all present-day India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Myanmar, except for small holdings by other European nations such as Goa (Portugal) and Pondicherry (France).
The British Raj invested heavily in infrastructure, including canals and irrigation systems.
The British Raj managed the defence, external affairs, and communications for the princely state and stationed a British Resident in Srinagar to oversee the internal administration.

The Constitution of 1956 was the fundamental law of Pakistan from March 1956 until the 1958 Pakistani coup d'état.
The Constitution of Pakistan (Urdu: آئینِ پاکستان, romanised: Ā'īn-e-Pākistān; also known as the 1973 Constitution) is the supreme law of Pakistan.
The Constitution of Pakistan of 1956 replaced the Pakistani monarchy with an Islamic republic.
The Constitution of Pakistan requires that the prime minister be a member of the National Assembly.
The Constitution states that all laws are to conform with the injunctions of Islam as laid down in the Quran and Sunnah.
The Constitution truly maintained a delicate balance between traditionalists and modernists and reflected heavy compromises on fundamental religious rights in the country.
The Constitution ultimately established a bicameral Parliament, with the National Assembly as the lower house and the Senate as the upper house.
The Constitution was promulgated in 1973 that reflected this equal balance and a compromise between Islamism and Humanism, and provided guaranteed equal human rights to all.
The Constitution was written in the point of representing the conservative Islam as well as reflecting a heavy compromise over the religious rights and humanism ideas, advocated by the PPP.

Pakistan was founded by Muhammad Ali Jinnah on August 14, 1947.
Muhammad Ali Jinnah is known as the Quaid-e-Azam of Pakistan.
The independence of Pakistan was achieved through the All-India Muslim League led by Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
Pakistan became an independent country in 1947 after the partition of India.
The first Prime Minister of Pakistan was Liaquat Ali Khan.
The first President of Pakistan was Iskander Mirza.
Pakistan fought wars with India in 1947, 1965, 1971, and 1999.
The 1971 war led to the creation of Bangladesh from East Pakistan.
Benazir Bhutto was the first female Prime Minister of Pakistan.
Pervez Musharraf was the President of Pakistan from 2001 to 2008.
The Constitution of Pakistan was adopted in 1956.
Pakistan joined the United Nations in 1947.
The national anthem of Pakistan was written by Hafeez Jalandhari.
The national flag of Pakistan was designed by Ameeruddin Kidwai.
